Women weren't always welcome on the bushwalking track

By Ruby Ekkel

Published: October 18, 2024 at 12pm AEST

Australians love a good bushwalk. It offers a chance to explore beautiful national parks, stretch our legs, and build friendships with fellow walkers. It’s even good for our mental health. But women weren’t always welcome on the bushwalking track.

As Melissa Harper has shown, bushwalking surged to popularity in the early twentieth century, peaking in the 1930s. Both men and women were keen participants, but some felt that women weren’t cut out to be walkers. Rugged encounters with nature were for men. Besides, how could female hikers deal with rocky paths and steep hills in long skirts and delicate shoes?

NH: are there any images of the club members in skirts, or perhaps just something to illustrate the garb of the time?

My new research brings to light the women who chose to walk anyway. The Melbourne Women’s Walking Club was formed in 1922, the first of its kind in Australia. Carrying homemade sleeping bags and a communal billy, club members defied expectations by walking all over Victoria and beyond, sometimes for weeks at a time.

NH: do we have an image of the women with all their gear?

These intrepid walkers faced stares, harassment and criticism, especially when they experimented with wearing pants (or even shorts!). But they found solace in friendship, love of nature, and the thrill of leaving behind the confines of city and home. And for some, bushwalking led to a lifelong passion for conservation.

The hard-earned success of the Melbourne Women’s Walking Club is a reminder of the ongoing issue of diversity in outdoor spaces. Everyone should feel safe and welcome on the bushwalking track, but we’re not there yet. [or does this go at the end?]

Let’s take a hike with the Melbourne Women’s Walking Club

In 1922, a group of women decided they weren’t satisfied with the occasional ‘Ladies Day’ offered by the male-only Melbourne Amateur Touring and Walking Club. And so the Melbourne Women’s Walking Club was born. The annual program offered between 30 and 40 walks catering to a range of abilities, as well as a busy social calendar. [could include sample annual program here] NH: yep, Matt this is an image possibility?

Though they were the first women’s walking club in Australia, they were not the only women bucking the trend. Other groundbreaking female walkers included Marie Byles, Dot Butler and Alice Manfield. [possible cool pic of Manfield] NH: yes please

In the early days, most bushwalks began at Flinders Street Station, where club members would take a train to the beginning of their hike. Women would wait until they were hidden from public view before stuffing their bulky skirts in their packs and swapping them for jodhpurs. NH: image of women in their jodhpurs here?

NH: image of Flinders street station, or perhaps map showing where they got the train to, and/or where they walked?

NH: Ruby, could we add a line or twp here about where the women travelled to bushwalking’s- Mount Buffalo, Mount Buller etc. Might help with map. And do you know of any specific walks they did? That might also help with map image

Club members took mealtimes seriously. For a weekend walking trip, the recommended packing list included: creamed rice, pre-cooked stew and vegetables, tinned pineapple and cream, grapefruit, eggs and bacon, steak for grilling over the campfire, six teaspoons of tea, and four of coffee. Finally, for tea on Sunday: two crumpets.[alternatively could just show this packing list as an image? otherwise I have some nice shots of the women eating together in the bush]

NH: image of women eating here. Let’s keep the description of the foods, I like it

Bushwalking could be dangerous and difficult. Margery Luth recalled a 1938 walk to Mount Buller which featured a broken-down bus, a hailstorm, and an overnight stay in a leaking shed. It doesn’t sound like a good time, but Luth found it thrilling. [alternative which could attach to a picture: there’s another story of a group of club members getting lost and running out of water, and eventually finding shelter for the night, and they take a photo grinning wildly together]

NH: I think we can include both examples, with a photo for the second example

In 1937, club member Olive Sandell fell off a cliff during an MWWC hike and passed away. Her devastated friend Molly Levvy wrote a poem in memory of her ‘pal who waits in the bush for me’. [could include poem?] NH: yep, great - and a scan of it?

MWWC members cherished these bushwalking friendships, and the opportunity to escape the busyness and pollution of city life. NH: how do we know this, Ruby - is there a quote from one of the walkers you could include? Perhaps we have a photo of a diary entry? It was also a chance to leave behind domestic spaces and responsibilities.

Why was a women’s walking club so controversial?

Women’s bushwalking seemed like an example of women’s increased independence in early-twentieth-century Australia. Many people thought this change was worth celebrating, and were glad to see women breaking new ground as walkers, cyclists and even rock-climbers.

Others were gravely concerned. The Archbishop of Brisbane thought the spectacle of women bushwalkers was ‘nauseating’, and warned that wearing pants might encourage boldness or risk-taking: ‘I know that young girls dressed in men’s garments would go to places where they would never venture in their proper attire’.

NH: Matt, could we grab an image of the newspaper article from that Trove link?

Some critics thought women only walked to attract attention or because it was the latest fad . These ideas led to unwelcome attention and lewd comments, especially when members took public transport to the beginning of each walk. [give example?] NH: yes please

Members recalled the relief of beginning the bushwalk, safe with friends and far from judgemental eyes. [could add MWWC article where they reflect on this]

NH: yes please - is there a scan of it? And could we have a quote to illustrate this sense of relief?

How bushwalking led to environmental activism with far-reaching impacts

In a time of changing environmental attitudes, bushwalking inspired a love of natural spaces and species.

Some club members became committed conservationists. Jean Blackburn, an enthusiastic member of the MWWC from 1934 to her death in 1983, played a leading role in the influential Report on Victorian National Parks. This report contributed to the creation of Victoria’s National Parks Authority and the National Parks Association. [think I could find a picture of her] NH: great, yes please

Elsewhere in Australia, Marie Byles led the creation of Bouddi National Park, and Jessie Luckman fiercely defended Mount Stead National Park. We can thanks early bushwalkers, including women, for many of the natural spaces we enjoy today.

NH: Matt, we could have a photo or two of the national parks as they are today?

Conclusion

More than 100 years later, the Melbourne Women’s Walking Club is still accepting new members and boasts its largest ever membership.

NH: it would be great to have a photo of the current bushwalkers

Thanks in part to the audacity of early female bushwalkers, it is no longer so controversial for women to go on unsupervised walks or wear shorts. But risks still exist for women in public spaces, and diversity in outdoor leisure remains a serious issue.

The club has made strides for women on the bushwalking track, but we still have a way to go before everyone feels welcome and safe in Australia’s great outdoors.

Ruby Ekkel

PhD candidate, Australian National University
